summary: This document is a chain of emails between Assistant U.S. Attorneys and Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys (Bobbi Sternheim, Laura Menninger, Jeff Pagliuca, Christian Everdell) regarding the logistics of reviewing physical and electronic evidence in the criminal case against Maxwell. The correspondence details negotiations over transporting evidence from an FBI warehouse in the Bronx to the 500 Pearl Street courthouse, scheduling review sessions with Maxwell present, and addressing disputes over access to highly confidential materials including nude images seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Lead defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, corresponding with prosecutors about evidence review logistics and access to highly confidential materials.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman representing Ghislaine Maxwell; primary correspondent negotiating evidence review terms with prosecutors.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney cc'd on all correspondence regarding evidence review logistics.

persons.name: Christian R Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell; cc'd on evidence review correspondence.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in case 20 Cr. 330; the emails discuss arrangements for her to be produced to 500 Pearl Street to review evidence with her defense team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the source of seized electronic devices, images, and evidence from his residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

connections.description: Sternheim is lead defense counsel representing Maxwell in the criminal case.
Menninger is a defense attorney representing Maxwell, negotiating evidence access on her behalf.
Pagliuca is a defense attorney on Maxwell's legal team.
Everdell is a defense attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Maxwell.
Evidence being reviewed was seized from Epstein's residences and devices, linking Maxwell to Epstein's activities.
Both are defense attorneys working together on Maxwell's case, coordinating on evidence review requests.

events.title: Evidence Review at Bronx Warehouse
events.description: Defense team scheduled to review evidence at FBI warehouse at 2350 Lafayette Ave, Bronx, NY from 11am to 4:30pm.

events.title: Evidence Review at 500 Pearl Street Begins
events.description: Start of evidence review at 500 Pearl Street courthouse with Ghislaine Maxwell present, scheduled from 8:30am/9:30am to 4:30pm daily.

events.title: Interview Recording
events.description: Reference to an original recording of an interview dated 4/24/07, a VHS tape located in FBI's ELSUR office in Florida to be shipped to New York.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (courthouse where evidence review with Maxwell takes place)
2350 Lafayette Ave, Bronx, NY (FBI warehouse where evidence is stored)
1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York U.S. Attorney's Office)
26 Federal Plaza, New York, NY (FBI office where cash evidence items are held)
FBI's ELSUR office in Florida (location of 2007 interview VHS tape)
Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and U.S. Virgin Islands (sources of seized evidence)
keyFacts: The defense sought to review all physical evidence, including approximately 2,100 previously undisclosed electronic nude/partially nude images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices.
Prosecutors revealed the FBI seized "plaster busts of female torsos" and "a stuffed dog" from Epstein's New York residence, items considered too bulky/fragile to transport.
A key point of contention was the government's refusal to allow review of "Sixteen DVD-R Discs from PBSO" (Florida Item 8, Subitem 8), prompting a separate government letter explaining the denial.

The evidence review required complex logistics: transporting evidence from a Bronx FBI warehouse, producing Maxwell from MDC, and using secure proffer rooms at 500 Pearl Street with restrictions on photography and electronic devices.

The correspondence reveals the massive scale of evidence, including thousands of electronic images, physical items from multiple investigations, and recordings in various obsolete formats (VHS, microcassette).
